div.p: Venerable and well-learned sir, on the 8th of this month, with Heinrich Zily, I sent you my latest letter, along with what was assigned to me at Rottenstein. Since then, I have received your letter along with the documents; I managed them on the 12th of this month. I thank you very much for the news, as well as the gifts, which I have shared with our dear lord preachers, who send you their kind and devoted greetings; they have let Mr. Kessler know the story before I sent it. My dear wife and I would also like to send you something that would please you; if we had something, it would be yours. Our people from Lyon have arrived, praise be to God, as I have reported. The Duke of Montpensier is said to have told his brother-in-law, the Duke of Guise, that when they had the pious Mr. Pigremont hanged, it was too much; they should see that it does not cause regret. From Nuremberg, I have heard that Ferdinand is to become king in Poland. That is all I have at this time. In ill. I thought ZÃ¶ger would stay until tomorrow. God be with you, yours, and all of us, amen. Greet Mr. Walther and other gentlemen for me, etc.
Your willing servant always, Hans Liner. To the venerable and well-learned Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, faithful servant of the Church of Christ, my honorable and beloved lord in Zurich.
